WmsRasterLayer.Name: Sea Surface Temperature
WmsRasterLayer.Description: The NCEP Sea Surface Temperature Product is a daily, high-resolution, global sea surface temperature.

AgsLayer.Name: Sea Surface Temperature Anomaly
AgsLayer.Description: SST anomaly is the difference between today's temperature and the long-term average. The scale goes from -5 to +5 Â°C. Positive numbers mean the temperature is warmer than average; negative means cooler than average.

AgsLayer.Name: Global Vegetation Health Index
AgsLayer.Description: VHI is a product characterizing vegetation health base on moisture and thermal conditions. VHI < 40 indicates vegetation stress; VHI > 60 is favorable condition.

AgsLayer.Name: Land Surface Temperature Anomaly - Daytime (8 Day)
AgsLayer.Description: Map showing land surface temperature anomalies for a week compared to the average conditions during that period between 2001-2010. Places that are warmer than average are red, places that were near-normal are white, and places that are cooler than average are blue. Black means there is no data.

AgsLayer.Name: Global Snow Cover (8 day)
AgsLayer.Description: Map of Earth's landscape covered by snow, the white areas show lands that were completely snow-covered on the dates shown, the light blue shades show regions in which there was only partial snow cover.

AgsLayer.Name: Global Leaf Area Index (8 Day)
AgsLayer.Description: Map showing how much an area is covered by leaves indicated by colors. The color palette range from tan, showing little or no leaf cover, to light green, indicating the area is entirely covered by one layer of leaves, to dark green showing thick forest canopies, where seven or more layers of leaves cover an area. Black means no data.

AgsLayer.Name: Global CO2 Retention by Vegetation (1 Month)
AgsLayer.Description: The colors on these maps indicate carbon absorption rate over 1 month period, Values range from -1.0 grams of carbon per square meter per day (tan) to 6.5 grams per square meter per day (dark green). A negative value means more carbon was released to the atmosphere than the plants took in.

AgsLayer.Name: Global Aerosol Optical Thickness (8 Day)
AgsLayer.Description: Aerosol (tiny solid and liquid particles) concentration over 8 days period. Dark brown pixels show high aerosol concentrations, while tan pixels show lower concentrations, and light yellow areas show little or no aerosols. Black shows where the sensor could not make its measurement.

AgsLayer.Name: Global Carbon Monoxide Concentration (1 Month)
AgsLayer.Description: Map showing monthly averages of carbon monoxide in the Earth's atmosphere. Different colors show the different amounts of gas in the troposphere at an altitude of about 12,000 feet.

AgsLayer.Name: Ocean Chlorophyll Concentration (8 Day)
AgsLayer.Description: Map showing where and how much phytoplankton were growing over 8 days period. Phytoplankton are tiny microscopic organisms that have chlorophyll to capture sunlight, and they use photosynthesis to turn it into chemical energy.

AgsLayer.Name: Tsunami Estimated First Wave Arrival Times
AgsLayer.Description: Estimated first wave arrival time forecasts for a pre-determined set of coastal locations from current time, updated every 5 minutes in real-time during a tsunami event. The time unit is expressed in hours, positive numbers for forward forecasts, and negative numbers for those locations where first waves have already passed.

AgsLayer.Name: CDC Health Alert Network (Point)
AgsLayer.Description: This layer displays notifications from the CDC Health Alert Network (HAN) which is the CDCs primary method of sharing cleared information about urgent public health incidents with public information officers, federal, state, territorial, and local public health practitioners, clinicians, and public health laboratories.

VirtualLayer.Name: CDC Health Alert Network
